required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Linking Inter-professional Newborn and Contraception Care
clinical_study.official_title: Linking Inter-professional Newborn and Contraception Care (LINCC) Trial - A Novel Approach to Postpartum Contraception Provision at the Well-Baby Visit

brief_summary.textblock: Pregnancies conceived within 18 months of a prior delivery (termed short inter-pregnancy interval [IPI]) place mothers and infants at high risk for poor health outcomes and affect nearly one third of women in the U.S. Rates of postpartum (PP) contraception use remain low, particularly among low-income minority women, leading to high rates of short IPI pregnancies. This proposed study aims to address the gap in the current model of PP contraception care, by developing and implementing a novel approach to link (co-schedule) PP contraception care with newborn well-baby care with the goal of improving access to timely PP contraception.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of patients who receive contraception by two months postpartum
primary_outcome.description: Using de-identified patient data collected through clinic's Electronic Health Record (EHR) system (i.e., visit type attended, billing codes for contraception) we will measure receipt of all methods of contraception by two months postpartum

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of patients who receive contraception by six months postpartum
secondary_outcome.description: Using de-identified patient data collected through clinic's Electronic Medical Record system (i.e., visit type attended, billing codes for contraception) we will measure receipt of all methods of contraception by six months postpartum

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of patients who present with a short inter-pregnancy interval pregnancies
secondary_outcome.description: Use data to estimate clinic-level rate of incoming prenatal patients presenting with short IPI

arm_group.description: During the intervention period (20 months), staff will capture women during the first well-baby visit (WBV; typically 3-5 days after delivery) and offer to have the next visit co-scheduled for infant and contraception care. Appointments are scheduled during the discharge process at the end of each WBV. During the discharge process all women 0-6 months postpartum will be identified by clerical staff through review of each pediatric clinic beforehand and through an electronic flag alert in the infant's electronic medical record. The pre-review of pediatric clinic schedules and the use of the flag will remind staff to offer the mother a co-scheduled visit for newborn and contraceptive care at the time of the next newborn visit.
Clinics will schedule postpartum contraception using normal clinic procedures.

intervention.description: Clinics will offer postpartum contraception appointments earlier and the opportunity to co-schedule these appointments with their infant's next well-baby visit

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Eligible participants include women presenting with their infants at one of the 14 chosen CHC sites for their first WBV (typically 3-5 days after delivery).
Exclusion Criteria:
- Women will be excluded if they had a tubal ligation or a long acting reversible contraception planned immediately after delivery. Additionally, women will be excluded if they needed an emergency hysterectomy due to life threatening bleeding during delivery. Any male patients will be excluded from the study because the study outcomes of contraceptive method use and pregnancy status are not applicable to males.

eligibility.gender_description: Eligible participants include women presenting with their infants at one of the participating locations of care for their first WBV (typically 3-5 days after delivery).
